childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1959-1971

You were born the year Fidel Castro marched into Havana, Alaska and Hawaii joined the union, and a plastic doll named Barbie became a cultural phenomenon. Dwight Eisenhower was president. The interstate highway system was transforming the American landscape. Television had just gone from novelty to necessity—nearly 90% of American homes had one.

Your childhood unfolded during what historians would later call the 'golden age' of American prosperity, though the shine was unevenly distributed. Suburbs sprawled outward. Station wagons filled driveways. Fathers worked. Mothers stayed home, allegedly content. The cracks in this façade wouldn't become obvious for a few more years.

You were four when JFK was shot in Dallas. Every adult around you remembers exactly where they were. You might have your own hazy memory of disrupted programming, of grown-ups crying at the television. Five years later, Martin Luther King Jr. and Bobby Kennedy were both assassinated within two months. By the time you were nine, you'd absorbed the lesson that America killed its idealists.

Your childhood home had a rotary phone, probably mounted to the kitchen wall. Air conditioning was a luxury. Color TV was coming but hadn't arrived yet. You played outside until the streetlights came on because there was nothing else to do. Video games, personal computers, mobile phones—these were science fiction, if they were even that.

The Vietnam War was background noise throughout your childhood, escalating on the nightly news while you did your homework. By the time you were old enough to understand what was happening, your older siblings or neighbors were being drafted. The war shaped your adolescence like nothing else—not because you fought in it, but because you watched your country tear itself apart over it.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Baby Boomers

You're a Baby Boomer, born between 1946 and 1964. That makes you part of the generation that resulted from 18 million GIs coming home from World War II and doing what soldiers do after wars. Your generation is roughly 76 million people in the US—the largest cohort in American history until Millennials eventually edged you out.

Born in 1959, you're on the younger end of the Boomer spectrum, sometimes called 'Late Boomers' or 'Generation Jones.' You weren't quite old enough to be a hippie at Woodstock (you were ten), but you caught the aftershocks. You inherited the counterculture second-hand—the music, the politics, the questioning of authority—without the draft card burning or the tear gas at Chicago.

Your generation's defining narrative is one of unprecedented opportunity: cheap college, plentiful jobs, affordable housing, pensions. But the timing within that generation matters enormously. Early Boomers caught the upswing. You caught the tail end, entering the workforce during the stagflation and oil crises of the late 1970s. The easy paths were already crowded.

Boomers are accused of pulling the ladder up behind them—defunding the institutions that lifted them, voting for policies that benefited themselves at the expense of future generations. Whether that's fair criticism or generational scapegoating depends on who's doing the talking. What's certain is that the world you grew up in no longer exists, and your children can't access the opportunities you took for granted.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Ben-Hur swept the Oscars and Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens, and the Big Bopper died in a plane crash in Iowa. Don McLean would later call it 'the day the music died,' but rock and roll was just getting started. Elvis was in the Army. Motown was about to launch. The British Invasion was five years away.

Your childhood soundtrack included the Beatles arriving on Ed Sullivan when you were four—an event that felt, even to a preschooler, like something important was happening. By the time you hit puberty, rock had splintered into a dozen directions: psychedelia, folk rock, hard rock, soul. You grew up with the Stones, the Doors, Hendrix, Janis Joplin. Your parents didn't understand any of it.

Television defined your childhood more than any previous generation. You watched the moon landing live at age ten. You saw Sesame Street premiere that same year. Walt Disney died when you were seven, but his kingdom lived on through Sunday night broadcasts that organized family schedules. Westerns dominated prime time until they suddenly didn't, replaced by sitcoms that pretended the 1960s hadn't happened.

Your teenage years coincided with the golden age of FM radio—album-oriented rock, freeform DJs, songs that stretched beyond three minutes. You bought vinyl. You studied album covers. You argued about whether Led Zeppelin or the Who was better. Music wasn't background noise; it was identity.

By the time you were in your twenties, disco had risen and fallen, punk had challenged everything, and MTV was about to change how music reached audiences forever. You're old enough to remember when music videos were revolutionary—when seeing a band perform in your living room felt like magic.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year the first integrated circuit was demonstrated—a piece of technology that would eventually put more computing power in your pocket than existed on the entire planet in 1959. But that was decades away. In your childhood, 'computer' meant a room-sized machine fed by punch cards, operated by men in lab coats.

Your first television was probably black-and-white. Color sets were expensive, and there wasn't much color programming anyway until the late 1960s. Watching the moon landing in 1969, when you were ten, might have been your first experience of technology as spectacle—proof that the future was arriving on schedule.

You were sixteen when the first personal computers appeared for hobbyists. Twenty when the Apple II brought home computing to the masses. Twenty-two when IBM released its PC, which became the standard for the next two decades. You were young enough to adapt but old enough to remember life without screens.

The internet arrived when you were in your thirties—first as a novelty, then as an inconvenience (dial-up), then as an essential utility. You learned email at forty, smartphones at fifty. You've watched technology advance more in your lifetime than in all previous human history combined, and you've kept pace, more or less.

Your relationship with technology is practical rather than native. You use it because you have to, because it makes certain things easier, but you remember when the alternative was fine. You can still read a paper map, balance a checkbook, look up a phone number in an actual book. These skills feel increasingly quaint, but they work when the Wi-Fi dies.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born the year Castro took Cuba. Ninety miles from Florida, a communist revolution succeeded, and the Cold War became literal neighbors. You were two during the Bay of Pigs fiasco, three during the Cuban Missile Crisis—thirteen days when nuclear annihilation felt imminent. You don't remember it, but it shaped the world you grew up in.

You were four when Kennedy was assassinated. Old enough to sense something terrible had happened, young enough for the details to blur. Five years later, you were nine when MLK was killed in Memphis, ten when Bobby Kennedy was shot in a Los Angeles hotel kitchen. By the time you reached double digits, you'd learned that hope was dangerous.

You were ten when Neil Armstrong walked on the moon. That was the promise kept—proof that the future was real, that anything was possible. Six months later, you turned eleven the same year the Manson murders and Altamont ended the Summer of Love's fantasy. The sixties left you with whiplash.

Vietnam escalated throughout your childhood and finally ended when you were sixteen. Watergate unfolded when you were in high school, watching a president resign in disgrace. The lessons of your adolescence were clear: authority lies, idealism fails, institutions are corrupt. You learned cynicism early.

You were eighteen when Saigon fell. Twenty when Jimmy Carter was struggling with inflation and the energy crisis. Twenty-one when Iranian students stormed the American embassy and held hostages for 444 days. By the time Reagan took office, when you were twenty-one, you'd already absorbed a lifetime of national humiliation.

You were thirty-two when the Berlin Wall fell, forty-two during 9/11, forty-nine during the 2008 financial crisis. You've watched the American century end and whatever comes next begin. History hasn't stopped—it's just started happening faster.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce in the late 1970s—not the best timing. The post-war boom was over. Stagflation combined high unemployment with high inflation, which economists had previously thought impossible. The oil crisis of 1973 and 1979 made everything more expensive. The easy jobs your older siblings found had dried up.

Your generation pioneered careerism. You dressed for success. You networked. You climbed corporate ladders that previous generations didn't know existed. The organization man gave way to the self-made professional. You were supposed to chart your own path, which really meant you were on your own if things went wrong.

You probably had one employer for most of your career, or maybe two or three. Job-hopping was still considered suspect. Loyalty was expected, even if it wasn't always reciprocated. You watched pensions disappear, replaced by 401(k)s that shifted retirement risk from employers to employees. The deal changed while you were mid-career.

If you're a woman, your career arc was complicated by expectations that Millennials can barely imagine. You were told you could have it all—career, family, fulfillment—as long as you did it perfectly and without complaint. The glass ceiling was very real and rarely acknowledged. Whatever you achieved, you achieved against headwinds that official narratives pretended didn't exist.

You probably retired around 2020, give or take, assuming you could afford to retire at all. Social Security is real for you—you'll actually collect it, unlike your children who view it as a theoretical construct. Your generation got the last reliable version of the American retirement: pension (if you were lucky), Social Security, maybe a paid-off house. The generations after you got none of that.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You came of age during the sexual revolution, which sounds more liberating than it often was. The pill became widely available when you were a teenager. Premarital sex stopped being universally scandalous. The rules your parents followed were suddenly optional, except nobody was quite sure what the new rules were.

You probably married younger than your children will—mid-twenties was standard. Divorce became normalized during your young adulthood; the rates peaked in the 1980s. Your generation experimented with serial monogamy, with open marriages, with the idea that relationships could be reinvented. Some experiments worked better than others.

Communication in your formative years meant face-to-face conversation, phone calls (on landlines, with cords), and handwritten letters. You learned to read body language, to interpret tone, to navigate silence. These skills are increasingly rare in a world where everything happens via text.

Your children grew up with technology you never had, creating a communication gap that's more than generational. They text; you call. They post; you tell stories. They have hundreds of online friends; you have a handful of people you've known for decades. Neither approach is wrong, but they don't always translate.

If you're still with your first spouse, you've beaten the odds. If you're on your second or third, you're part of a pattern your generation normalized. The idea that marriage is one-size-fits-all gave way to the recognition that people change, that staying together isn't always the right choice, that personal fulfillment matters. Whether that represents progress or decline depends on your theology.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Your parents survived the Depression. That memory shaped how they handled money—save everything, waste nothing, trust no institution. You inherited some of that caution, but prosperity made it feel obsolete. Credit cards arrived. Mortgages were cheap. The stock market climbed. Why hoard when abundance felt permanent?

You bought your first house when houses were affordable. The average home price in 1985, when you were twenty-six, was about $75,000—roughly three times the median income. By 2024, that ratio had more than doubled. The wealth you accumulated through homeownership wasn't primarily because you were smarter than your children; it was because you were earlier.

You watched the stock market boom and crash, boom and crash. The dot-com bubble. The 2008 collapse. Each time, you were told the fundamentals were sound. Each time, the fundamentals weren't. You learned that the market is a casino with better PR, but you kept playing because the alternatives were worse.

Your generation's wealth concentration is historically unprecedented. Boomers hold more than half of America's wealth, compared to 7% for Millennials at the same age. Some of that is fair—you've had longer to accumulate. But some of it reflects structural advantages that no longer exist: affordable education, defined-benefit pensions, housing that cost less than a decade of rent.

Retirement, if you've reached it, probably looks nothing like your parents' retirement. They worked, stopped, died. You're dealing with decades of post-career life—healthcare costs that compound annually, the possibility of outliving your savings, the question of whether to downsize or stay put. The golden years turn out to require a lot of financial planning.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's biggest blind spot is the belief that your success was entirely earned. It was partly earned—you worked hard, made sacrifices, took risks. But it was also partly structural. You came of age when unions were strong, when college was cheap, when one income could support a family. Those conditions weren't your achievement; they were your context.

You tend to assume that what worked for you should work for everyone. Pull yourself up by your bootstraps. Just get a job. Walk in and ask for the manager. This advice isn't wrong so much as outdated—it describes a world that no longer exists. The path you walked has been paved over, and pointing to it as if it's still there doesn't help anyone.

Your generation's relationship with technology is often characterized by suspicion that shades into dismissal. You didn't grow up online, so online life can feel trivial, narcissistic, less real than the alternatives. But for younger generations, online is where life happens—careers, relationships, politics, identity. Dismissing it dismisses them.

You were raised to believe in institutions—government, corporations, marriage, religion—that have since proven less trustworthy than advertised. Your tendency is to reform these institutions rather than replace them. Younger generations, having watched those institutions fail repeatedly, are more inclined to burn it all down. Both approaches have merit; neither has a monopoly on wisdom.

Your generation got the planet at a particular moment—post-war abundance, cheap energy, seemingly infinite growth. The environmental costs of that abundance were hidden or ignored. Climate change is happening on your watch, with consequences your grandchildren will pay. This isn't entirely your fault, but pretending it's not partially your responsibility doesn't hold up.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1979-1989): You entered adulthood during economic turbulence—oil crises, stagflation, recession. The easy paths were crowded. You hustled, competed, built credentials. Reagan's morning in America was more complicated than the branding suggested. You got married, probably. Started a family, probably. Bought a house, definitely—they were still affordable. This was the decade where you established the foundation for everything after.

Your 30s (1989-1999): The Cold War ended. The economy boomed. Technology transformed everything. You advanced in your career, reached middle management or better, accumulated assets that would appreciate faster than wages. Your kids were school-aged. Your parents were healthy. This was the sweet spot—old enough to have authority, young enough to have energy. The 1990s felt like they might last forever.

Your 40s (1999-2009): Y2K was a fizzle. 9/11 was not. Your forties included the Iraq War, the housing bubble, and the financial crisis that nearly collapsed the global economy. Your kids became teenagers, then adults. Your parents started aging in ways that required attention. You hit peak earning years while watching retirement savings evaporate in 2008. The future felt less certain than it had a decade earlier.

Your 50s (2009-2019): Recovery, slow and uneven. You helped your kids through college, paid tuition that had tripled since you attended. Your parents needed more help, then passed away. The sandwich generation squeeze was real—responsibilities on both ends, limited support for either. You started thinking seriously about retirement, about legacy, about what comes next.

Your 60s (2019-2029): You're in this decade now. COVID reshaped your final working years or early retirement. Grandchildren, if you have them, are growing up in a world you barely recognize—climate anxiety, school shootings, politics as tribal warfare. You're trying to stay relevant while accepting that relevance might not be the point anymore. Your health is the variable that determines everything else.

Your 70s and beyond (2029+): The actuarial tables say you have about a decade of good years left, then a gradual decline. Healthcare will be your largest expense. Mobility, cognition, independence—these will narrow. You'll tell stories about the world before the internet, before smartphones, before everything changed. Whether anyone listens depends on relationships you built decades ago. The finish line approaches. What you leave behind is already determined. What remains is how you spend what's left.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 4.2 million people born in 1959. The entire Baby Boomer generation is about 76 million people in the US, making it the largest generation in American history for most of your lifetime.

Compared to the Silent Generation (born 1928-1945), you're louder. They came of age during Depression and war, learned to keep their heads down, follow rules, build quietly. You came of age during abundance and questioned everything. They trusted institutions; you distrusted them. They saved; you spent. They were grateful; you were entitled. Or so the stereotypes go.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you're more optimistic—or you were. Gen X grew up as latchkey kids, raised themselves while you built careers. They're cynical in ways you find depressing, realistic in ways you find dismissive. They got the leftovers of the prosperity you enjoyed and learned to expect less. They'll never forgive you for it, and they're not entirely wrong.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), the contrast is stark. You bought houses; they pay rent. You had pensions; they have student loans. You graduated into opportunity; they graduated into the Great Recession. The generational wealth gap is the widest in American history, and you're on the winning side. They're not bitter—they're exhausted. The system that worked for you broke before they could use it.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're from different planets. They've never known a world without smartphones, without school shootings, without climate crisis. They're anxious in ways you can't quite understand, pragmatic in ways that look like resignation. They don't expect Social Security to exist when they retire. They might be right.

Your life expectancy at birth was about 70 years. Modern medicine has extended that—you can reasonably expect to reach 80, maybe longer with good genes and good luck. You've outlived more assumptions than any generation before you. The world you were born into has vanished. The world you'll leave behind is unrecognizable. That's the Boomer experience: everything changed, including you.

year_events: Fidel Castro took power in Cuba
Buddy Holly died in a plane crash
